docs.text: Welcome to the project wiki.

docs.title: 🌟 Custom ROS 2 Node Example
docs.text: Publishes a simple “Hello World!” message every second using a custom message type. Ideal for getting started with ROS 2 publishers and timers.

docs.title: ✅ Topics
docs.text: Topic Type Description /hello_world custom_pkg/msg/Custom Custom message with a string

docs.title: ⚙️ Parameters
docs.text: No parameters used in this node.

docs.title: 📦 Message Notes
docs.text:
• Custom:
  • string custom_msg

This node publishes the string "Hello World!" as the content of custom_msg.

docs.title: 🧩 Implementation Notes
docs.text:
• Built with rclcpp.
  • Uses a 1-second timer to trigger publishing.
  • Simple custom message custom_pkg::msg::Custom.
  • Logging is used to indicate node startup.

docs.title: 🏁 Launch Example
docs.text: ros2 run custom_pkg custom_node

docs.title: 🧪 Dependencies
docs.text:
• rclcpp
  • Custom message in custom_pkg:
  • Custom.msg

docs.text:
For contributing we recommend creating a fork and when ready a pull request to merge the changes with this repository. In the pull request please state:

  • What has been added/changed?

Please don't do refactors without consent of administrators as we will not merge them.

docs.title: 🔊 1. Start Custom Node
docs.text:
Does some hello world publishing on hello_world topic:

ros2 run custom_pkg custom_node

docs.title: Getting started with Pixi
docs.text: Pixi makes cross-platform ROS 2 development easy. You can build and run both capture and playback nodes on Linux and Windows—with no system-wide ROS install.

docs.title: 📦 Install Pixi
docs.text:
Linux:

curl -fsSL https://pixi.sh/install.sh | bash

Windows (PowerShell):

powershell -ExecutionPolicy ByPass -c "irm -useb https://pixi.sh/install.ps1 | iex"

docs.title: 🚀 Clone & Build Project
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/CLFML/ROS2_Package_Template.git
cd ROS2_Package_Template
pixi install
pixi run build

Or launch VSCode with the environment:

pixi run vscode

✅ Note (Windows): Always build in Release or RelWithDebInfo, not Debug! (Ctrl+Shift+P → "CMake: Select Variant")

docs.title: ⚡ Using as a Pixi Dependency
docs.text: Want to use custom_pkg from another Pixi-based project?

docs.title: 1. Init a new project
docs.text:
mkdir my_project && cd my_project
pixi init

docs.title: 2. Edit pixi.toml
docs.text:
Add these:

[project]
channels = [
  "https://fast.prefix.dev/conda-forge",
  "https://prefix.dev/robostack-jazzy",
  "https://clfml.github.io/conda_ros2_jazzy_channel/"
]

[dependencies]
ros-jazzy-ros-base = "*"
ros-jazzy-custom_pkg = "*"
colcon-common-extensions = "*"
rosdep = "*"

docs.title: 🧠 Optional: VSCode Support
docs.text:
Add to your pixi.toml:

[target.linux-64.dependencies]
python-devtools = "*"
pybind11 = "*"
numpy = "*"

[target.win-64.dependencies]
python-devtools = "*"

[target.linux-64.tasks]
vscode = 'env -u LD_LIBRARY_PATH code .'

[target.win-64.tasks]
vscode = "code ."

docs.title: 3. Run the nodes
docs.text:
pixi install
pixi run ros2 run custom_pkg custom_node

docs.title: 🐧 Getting Started with Native ROS
docs.text: Prefer a traditional system-wide install? Use the prebuilt .deb package for Ubuntu Noble / ROS 2 Jazzy.

docs.title: 📦 Install package via .deb
docs.text:
Install the latest .deb package directly from Releases:

curl -s https://api.github.com/repos/CLFML/ROS2_Package_Template/releases/latest \
  | grep "browser_download_url.*deb" \
  | cut -d : -f 2,3 \
  | tr -d \" \
  | wget -qi -
sudo dpkg -i ./ros-jazzy-*.deb

docs.title: ✅ Run the Nodes
docs.text:
Make sure ROS is sourced:

source /opt/ros/jazzy/setup.sh

ros2 run custom_pkg custom_node
